pros: Nashua is a nice community to work in, and the students are nice to work with. Lots of great colleagues who go out of their way to help and welcome new colleagues.
cons:
Nashua is a nice community but campus is intersected by multiple roads which make a less than appealing aesthetic. Some campus improvements in recent years have made for a more visually appealing campus, but campus still looks outdated, more like a community college than a private institution.

More importantly, there are a number of fear-based management tactics at work here. While other colleges are evolving to be more employee friendly, Riv quickly shuts down any such discussions so employees don't even feel comfortable talking about things like remote work openly.

Since facilities management was outsourced earlier in the year, upkeep of campus facilities have started a clear downward trend.

review_title: ideal candidate will have low standards and no long term goals
pros:
1. Close parking most of the time 

2. Fairly generous time off 

3. Tuition benefit if you have a child/spouse looking to complete their bachelor's
cons:
1. You are expected to bend over backwards for the international student population while enduring great abuse from them. Full time day students do NOT receive the same special treatment as international graduate students. International students are allowed to turn shoddy work in late, receive outrageous tuition payment extensions, etc. all in the name of keeping them around. Sister Paula works hard to protect these students at any expense - will allow them to treat staff with disrespect, foul language, and attitude that would not be tolerated from other students. 

2. Pay is low. Take whatever you're thinking and subtract, subtract, subtract. 

3. No chance for advancement. Upper management has been there for 20+ years. No new opportunities. 

4. For a work environment of mainly middle aged people it sure feels a lot like high school. Gossip, backstabbing, slander, etc. If you can stay out of it you will do fine. 

5. No transparency from upper management. Little communication. Lots of finding out about things the same time as students. Lots of seemingly random policy changes with little to no explanation. 

TL;DR - not a bad place to get your feet wet, but not anywhere you want to get comfortable. If you have thick skin and a cheap lifestyle you might be okay. If you're looking to be fulfilled, feel like you're making a difference, or leave each day with some dignity in tact- look elsewhere.

pros: Freedom of curriculum. Dedication of the department staff
cons: Resource allocation. Room for upward mobility

Poor leadership by senior management; All think that their area is the only area of the college. There is a lot of people who have a high sense of importance and think the school would shut down if they did not come to work. There are also people who would be perfectly happy if the school could run without students. 

Very outdated and archaic methods in the way this place is run. Also has extremely LOW salaries. It is a small school so there are few if any chances for advancement. There is a high turnover among staff as people get tired of being treated like a pee-on for low pay and move on to something better.

Employees used to receive tuition benefits- classes covered (2 per semester) at no cost to employee. Now you can NOT register until one week to the day before the start of a course unless you want to receive a bill. I totally respect preference going to paying students, but do not advertise this as a benefit when clearly it is not.

review_title: Wonderful experience working as an adjunct.
